title: My name is Ocho... Anet A8 - AKA TheOCHO

description.text:
My name is Ocho... Anet A8

This are 2 decorative pieces for your Anet A8...

Are they reinforcement braces? Well yes, but I haven't tested them enough to confirm they actually do anything else that looking nice :P You be the judge and if you like them, share with your friends.

Print notes: The base of the A can be quiet a challenge, I print them standing and with supports and the base of the A can be messy. I believe a better way to print them would be laying face down. (I don't have enough experience with my printer to confirm what would work better)

Supports are needed for sure. I used 3 perimeters with a 0,4 nozzle and did 0,24 layer height. (Again I don't think I printed them on the optimal orientation so feel free to print it however you like)

General Notes:
You can use the same screws that your printer has right now.
If you have any modification on the print head carriage make sure this update wont hit anything when the axis is up there. On default stock A8 it clear X axis endstop and the bearings with no problem.

author: glehlaing

description.text:
Parametric Massager

This is a set of OpenSCAD scripts for generating a vibrating massage wand. It is designed to be as modular and hackable as possible. You will need to modify the files to fit your motor, electronics and tube.

Vitamins

  • A short piece of rubber hose, I used a piece of garden hose in my initial tests.
  • A small electric motor (I used an RS260)
  • Electronics for controlling the motor
  • Appropriately sized hose clamps or zip ties
  • 4x M3 cap screws and hex nuts (The length of these will depend on the size of the tip)

This massage wand is designed to be modified to accept any electronics you wish to put in it and as such, the provided enclosure is very basic. You will need to modify the enclosure to fit your particular electronics. I may update this project in the future to include some electronics and an appropriate enclosure.

Massager Tip (tip.scad)

Follow the comments in the file explaining what the variables do. You will probably want to choose a motor diameter slightly larger than your motor, it is easy to make the motor a little larger by wrapping it in some electrical tape afterwards to get a snug fit.

There are two halves to the massager tip, set top to true for the top half, or top to false for the bottom half. The top half is designed to retain the nuts.

This will need to be printed with support enabled and the open side facing down.

Vibration mass (vibe_mass.scad)

This is a simple off center mass that is attached to the motor in order to make it vibrate. The overall width from the center of the shaft to the outside of the mass is equal to d2/2 + spacing. I would recommend leaving a couple of millimeters on all sides for clearance.

Enclosure / Handle (handle_v1.scad)

You will likely need to modify this to fit any electronics you plan on putting into it. It is parametric, so you simply need to adjust the inside dimensions and generate the part. You may also wish to add standoffs for a PCB, holes for buttons or other features before printing.

Head Cover (head_cover.scad)

This is an optional cover for the massager that helps prevent fluid ingress. It is designed to be printed in a flexible filament such as TPU and slipped over the tip of the massager. Follow the instructions in the file for usage.

Head Cover (head_cover.scad)

Same as above, but designed to be a bit easier to print.

Tube (tube.scad)

If you don't have a piece of tube handy, you can print this tube in a flexible filament. This is entirely optional and can be replaced by a short piece of tube from your local hardware store.

title: Coolice XY Idler Mount Left & Right

description.text:
Hey All.

This is just a simple change to the XY Idler Mounts, both the left & right sides.

Bascially I've switched the M3 clamping screw & brass inserts around, so with the GT2 idler pulleys fitted you can get to the M3 screws clamping the 10m diameter Y axis guide rods from outside of the Hypercube.
The original design has the screw heads hidden by the pulleys, so you can't undo the clamping action once assembled.

Update 2/1/2018 ; New version added suitabel for M3 nuts rather than brass inserts

comments.text:
This parts should have been this way from the start!
Better, only with M3 nuts, if you're up for the challenge ;)

title: Prusa MK2 RPI Zero Camera mount v2

description.text: Compared to the previous version this RPI 0 camera holder keeps the RPI vertical and does not move with the bed.

Install

I printed for the right side because it is there that I put my 5v charger. You can mirror it to obtain the left one.
Once you have printed it, simply unscrew the three screws holding the z-motor and place the holder there.
Put back the screws and enjoy your octopi

Fix focus

Print https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1574661 and you'll be able to fix the focus of your pi camera.

description.text:
This is a holder for a Half Bridge Load Sensor (https://www.sparkfun.com/products/10245, Cheap on ebay too).

I'm using this with a Load Sensor Combinator (not needed, but makes it dead simple)
https://www.sparkfun.com/products/13878

I am also using a Load Cell Amplifier (Amazon/ebay has HX711 chips too)

author: pjanky

print_settings.Notes:: increased the raft vertical to 0.3 mm for separation. (possibly only meaningful for makerbot)

description.text:
After printing Mathgrrl's Total Eclipse pendant (www.thingiverse.com/thing:2481857), I wanted to create a pinhole design. So I thought of just a blank insert with a pinhole. but that was dull. Videos show people uses colanders and I was wondering if the shape of the pinhole mattered.

Technically, there is a top and bottom with the edge slightly tilted inward. I can't tell with the physical print though.

Depending on which side is facing you, the outer row is concave, the inner row is convex and the center is cylindrical (we should get at least one good pinhole shadow). Otherwise the opposite is true. There is no wrong way!!

No guarantees of effectiveness but can't wait to find out together on August 21st.

Update: It worked awesome! when I first tried it, i thought the holes were too big and nothing was working. However, I had first tested it when the partial had just started so the crescent shape wasn't as present. I tried it again about a half hour before totality and it was wonderful. I took this pictures at that that time. note: the picture of the sun was taken with my iPhone with the eclipse glass "lens" placed over the camera's actual lens.

There is no significant difference between the convex and concave holes at least at this distance. more holes the better.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

increased the raft vertical to 0.3 mm for separation. (possibly only meaningful for makerbot)

I used an X-Acto K-nife for post processing. Also, had to mark which circle I started with. rotated once around, moved in one row, rotated, cleaned cylinder, flipped and repeated. Could use polishing but should be effective

OpenSCAD plus Guessing

I used OpenSCAD after obtaining the diameter of the Corona from Mathgrrl's Total Eclipse Pendant (www.thingiverse.com/thing:2481857). By creating a simple cylinder of depth (height) and diameter to fill in where the moon would be during the actual eclipse, I designed a convex and a concave cylinder of the same height. I thought about using mirror but then I just resorted to good old basic trig and a for loop. by rendering using f5, I could guess where the "holes" should be and adjust accordingly.

Note: because each object was referencing the "moon", I never had to place center equal to true.

title: Singlespeed spacers for Mountain bike hubs

description.text: This is a collection of different spacers to make a conversion to singlespeed for mountain bikes. You can use a mtb cassete and use the cog with the desired teeth count and use the threaded cap. I suggest you use measure the position of the cog and calculate the combinations of the different sizes of spacers. A solidworks model is provided so you can also set the size of the spacer you want. I suggest you leave approximately 1mm sticking out of the hub body so the threaded cap can provide enough clamping force. Also, you should print a test spacer and adjust the scale. 101% scale provides enough clearance and makes it easier to mount.

Printer:

Homemade

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25

comments.text: I've done headset spacers and discovered the easiest approach was to make one at 10mm and then scale it in the slicer in the Z axis to the height needed. 5mm - scale 50% in Z, etc. Math is easy and less need for individual parts.

title: Keymod Rails Segments
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
These are keymod attachment rails for use with keymod RIS/RAS rails.

I have made several sizes to try and make as much usefull sizes as I could think of that are still compatible with the original keymod sizing. There are 3, 5, 7, 9, 13 and 17 spacing versions available.

My design uses the original sizing for the keymod nuts, but they have M3 nuts inserted into them for a much stronger grip.

This goes great with my keymod RAS rail design.

Printer:

Gemstock - Azurite

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15mm layer height

Infill:

25%-50%

Notes:

Make sure your prints are strong because there are quite some forces on the rails when in use.

Mounting the rail

After removing the support from the keymod nuts you will have to place the M3 nut into the slots, they might be snug so using a pair of pliers or a vice is recommended.

After that, thread the screw partially through the rail segment and onto the keymod nut.ever so slightly engaging the thread of the M3 nut itself.

Then place your segment onto the rail as per usual and tighten down untill satisfied.

comments.text: What size bolt/screw and nut do i need for this to work?
comments.author: SixFootDworf

comments.text:
You will need M3 nuts and bolts to attach these rails onto your rails.
I myself used M3x10mm bolts, your might need to be a bit longer/shorter depending on your rails.
comments.author: SixFootDworf

comments.text:
Take a look a my version: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1824399
Your nut looks good but the rails need the stopping edged on the bottom.
comments.author: ripper121

comments.text:
I have indeed looked at the notch/edge on the bottom, but with the M3 nut in there there is enough retention to keep the rails in place.
I chose to not include them because the cleanliness would go down and the difficulty would go up if I did, and I wanted to have quite simple to print rails.
comments.author: ripper121

author: joselo1974

title: The Monolith 50mm E3D V6 Shroud Fanduct

description.text:
I'll make a E3D V6 Volcano version soon and both V5 versions. Since I also have such a hotend and heatsink laying around. But I'll redesign it from scratch, because my old fusion 360 file takes way too long to load because it had too many additions and extrusion. But I keep learning new things.
I also printed quite a bit with this new shroud, and it works fine at 150mm/s setting in cura, eventhough the anet cannot reach those speeds. And nothing has melted yet at 270 degrees.
Edit: Set your fan speed to 100% if you need to bridge.

Assembly:
The E3D V6 heatsink might have a very tight fit or it does not fit at first. You need to push it into the plastic pretty hard. I took the direct dimensions with a caliper, and even removed 0.01mm here and there. But I also wanted to prevent resonance so it’s a very tight fit.

This shroud should fit on any groovemount if there is enough room at the front. I kept about 1mm of space between the back of the plastic and the back of the heatsink. So there would always be 1 mm free space for the hot air to espace and to solve any mounting issues.

When you want to screw this shroud to the groovemount, you might need drill out the holes at the top. I made these to be 3.0mm, the diameter of a M3 screw, but I had some filament in between so I had to drill it out very slightly. These groovemount screwholes should give no resistance.

On my own AnetA8 I could remove the extra X-stop and I now use the default X-stop location. Because this shroud is (surprisingly) not as wide as I initially thought.

When I mounted this to my own X-carriage (which is very butchered) I had to screw it together with quite some force but not too much force to get everything to fit tightly. But it won’t go anywhere now.

For reference of the width of the screw holes that I used, I used these groovemount X-carriage for the Prusa i3 and AnetA8:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2099577 ANET A8 | Customizable E3D v6 Carriage / Bowden mount by TNS, published Feb 12, 2017

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1632847 E3Dv6 Bowden X-carriage mount v2 for Prusa i3 by Tech2C, published Jun 18, 2016

I kept this thing as a whole block due to mounting weight and the lack of space for a mounting block.

I did kept in account that screw heads are about 4.7mm in diameter so I made the grooves to be 5mm.

For mounting the fans I used M3 screws, and made the holes to be 2.9mm so it grips on the plastic when you screw it in. The screwholes for the fans are 6mm deep into the plastic. I used 20mm screws myself for these fans. The screwhole walls are 1mm or more so it should not break easily.

There should be around 2 to 3mm of space between the lowest part of the fanduct and the tip of the E3D nozzle. These fanducts blow directly and a bit below the nozzle. Atleast I hope that it does that, I’m not a wind engineer. But you can inspect the STL file if it’s to your liking. I test printed some frogs which had an overhand at their chin and belly and that worked out very well, with 35% fan speed.
I printed this with 2 walls and 15% infill. Use whatever setting you like but so note that the mounting pressing for the heatsink to fit onto the plastic is pretty high.

Extra information and reasoning:

This is a triple 50mm fan shroud that I made for 2 purposes:

  1. Actually fit on the X-carriage groove mount for E3D heatsinks.
  2. To be able to use 50mm silent fans.
    [3. To not resonate when I’m printing fast]

It’s a large block, but surprisingly not as wide as the other shrouds that I printed from other people. Multiple plastic parts that are held down with bolts can have small gaps and can resonate at high print speeds (60+ mm/s). I also kept about 7mm of space in between the heatingblock and the plastic shroud so the plastic does not soften when I print at 270 degrees Celsius or hotter. (for stronger layer adhesion as the filament melts into the previous layers. Skynet3D has a safety shut down at 275 degrees, but I’ll be using a pt100 thermocouple soon to print POM or PETG)
For me there is enough space in between the heating block and the plastic shroud; I use Chinese clone parts to tinker around.

I made this fan shroud in fusion 360, with too much effort by only using the model tools. So I used a lot of sketches and extrusions. I should have used the sculpt tools instead.
I used these fans:
Gelid Solutions Silent 5
Size: 50 mm
Noise: 23 dB
Airflow: 21,94 m³/h
Airflow: 12,91 cf/m
Max RPM: 4.000rpm

These cost me about 5 euro’s a piece. And they are pretty silent, as they do make noise but at a lower frequency pitch. It's more like a blowing noise instead of a tearing noise that'll hear on turbine fans. But due to my design faults, it can cause turbulence which makes the fans a bit louder than when you do not mount them. And these fans pull/suck a lot of air in. I might put a tachometer in between so I can regulate the fan speed for the heatsink. The filament coolers can be controlled by the board/slicer software. But at the moment my anet a8 frame is squeaking louder than the noise of the fans.

Apparently if You write here your token expires and you'll loose all your text.
Should have know that, as for my previous experiences with writing on thingyverse.
As you can read here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/PokeyDoggo/collections/anet-a8-early-upgrades
https://www.thingiverse.com/PokeyDoggo/collections/e3d-v6-hotend-filament-coolers

So there goes half an hour of typing and getting the right data and pictures.
I'll update this with a proper description if I feel like it.

Yes I have multiple heatsinks and heaterblocks. One used, one not yet used.

author: Spirit00

description.text:
The garden hose adapter broke from my kids sprinkler toy and rather than buy a new one, I modeled up a nipple to fit and merged with it the Hose Cap by rue_mohr.

Took three iterations to get it right. There are the pseudo-fillets for better lateral force distribution.

You will need to drill out the center as I kept the cap roof solid for stability since this prints with no rafts and scale the nipple if you bring it in as an individual model.

There is 100% in-fill for maximum rigidity. Next test is if it survives "the children!" LOL!

The original nipple STL is included and if you want the CAD file, just let me know.

title: Tool plate for Magnetic Mounting plate Thingy (25mm conduit)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a base plate for tools. Check out my Magnet Mounting plate Thingy (25mm conduit) to distinguish the magnet holes from the rampa nut holes.

LINK: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1675690

There is 0,5mm space between the two part, except for the bottom of the rest pin.
You can use a tool (can't refer to "THE" tool at the moment) to let the magnets stick out a bit, so that the holes on the side allign 100%. The holes on the side allign with the rampa nuts in the mount plate.

The 5 rampa nut holes in the middle are for something like a dual E3D mount like https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1222291

Upper holes for the ajustment bar are a lineair pattern of 25mm.
Lower holes (4) have the following distance 6,75mm from the middle and the 2 holes on each side are 16,75mm apart from eachother.

(see messy picture)

P.S. will make a tool to push in the magnets and let them stick out 0,4 / 0,3 / 0,2 / 0,1mm
plane ball shaped shifter nob

title: Paohedra
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: http://web.sfc.keio.ac.jp/~t10544nt/paohedra/ Paohedra is a moduler paper craft system created by Nao Tsushima. You can make your own polyhedron by combining Paohedra modules. All modules have the same shape, but they can be combined in variety of ways to make different polyhedra.

• Download the data.

  • Print it out on a semi-stiff paper and cut out the shapes. Or cut it out with CNC paper cutter.

  • Assemble them into the shape you like.

remixed_from.title: Improved Spool Holder for the Original Prusa i3 MK2

title: Prusa i3 MK2 Spool Holder with Filament Guide

description.text:
Modification to Mirkoengineer's spool holder (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2171625). I printed it out and realized I also needed a filament guide to keep the filament from popping off the spool and it needed to be high enough to clear the extruder at maximum Z height. I was pleased to see that Mirkoengineer provided drawing files I could load into OnShape! (Thanks!). I added a guide to the base model and it seems to work pretty well.

I've included drawing files as well as the STL. Also, here's a link to my OnShape drawing:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/e23797d7a9617283ac3ece32/w/13237e973352e0c58b750e77/e/0d9774bf02f25e4fac2781cf

title: 20 x 20 Maker Rail V-Slot Locking Foot!

description.text:
So when you have am itch you need to simply sctrach it and that is what we did with this build as we needed feet for a 20 x 20 Maker Rail V-Slot project we where building (see it here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2486606) so whipped these up in Tinkercad and designed them to work with a #10 Magic Nut Thing (also included with foot) as they receive two felt pads (http://amzn.to/2vEiYn2) to provide a professional finished look to the project.

Update: Added a 27mm (or 1 Inch) foot version (original was 38mm or 1.5 inches)

1-1/2-Inch Surface Grip Adhesive Non Slip Pads:
http://amzn.to/2xJuOeu

Need some V-Slot Maker Rail:

description.text:
When I got my CR-10 I was busily printing away with the provided PLA until I decided to try some PLA i had had sitting around for a long time - but the spool diameter was too small to fit over the provided spool holder! Since I had 10 more of these spools all sealed up and ready to use I made this replacement spool holder. You can customize the width and diameter to use whatever spools you may have. You can also make the rod as solid as you dare... I kept it conservative and print time was about 6 hours. Hope this helps someone.
Designed with OpenSCAD and uses the thread library found here:
http://dkprojects.net/openscad-threads/
Just a heads-up, rendering the threads takes quite a long time in OpenSCAD so don't worry if it takes a while.

Printer:

CR-10

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

Printed on CR-10 in PLA at 220 using spool provided with printer, and 210 with other PLA.
2 perimeters, 3 horizontal shells, 5mm brim, 30% honeycomb, at 50mm/sec. Sliced with Slic3r 1.1.7
Given the way the weight of the spool distributes good layer adhesion is very important.

Clean up the threads. I found that after removing the worst that working the nut back and forth on the threads cleaned up the rest pretty well. Printed the threads on the nuts at slightly larger diameter (internal thread 31.4mm dia v. 29.9 dia on external thread) to eliminate needing fanatically perfect cleanup.

description.text:
Introducing the MPSCARA!

WARNING: This project is still a work in progress, we cannot promise that it will run as well as intended, but are committed to helping everyone get their machines operating as smoothly as possible. It still requires a lot of polish, but we will be continuing with our updates as we produce them. Thank you for your patience, please comment or message with any issues you run into while building/using your MPSCARA and we will do our best to help!

This is a SCARA robotic arm designed to be a cheap, compact, and easy-to-build 3D printer. It can also be equipped with a marker (An older version of the MPSCARA using the marker can be found here), with further tools potentially on the way. It is heavily based off Idegraaf's design, with some quality-of-life updates added in.

If you are interested in building one yourself, download the V1_MPSCARA.zip file and crack it open. It contains...

  • V1.X Marlin - Preconfigured marlin firmware for your MPSCARA V1
  • V1.X Software - A Python-based gcode conversion script, complete with usage instructions and comments.
  • V1.X STL Files - A full repository of STL files needed to build your very own MPSCARA V1
  • Bill of Materials V1.X - In excel and pdf formats, complete with prices and links to where the components may be purchased. Note: Most hardware will be available at nearby hardware stores, and likely sold in lower bulk than online, I strongly suggest you check those locations first to get better deals.
  • MPSCARA Instructions V1.X - Also known as a process plan or construction instructions, this tells you exactly how to build, wire up, and install the firmware onto your MPSCARA.

As the file names imply, this is the first iteration of all these distinct components. If any issues are encountered, or any clarifying questions arise, the files will be updated along with notes on this page to indicate what was changed and why (Along with version increments on the related files). That being said, please comment on here or PM me with questions or suggestions for this project.

Special thanks to Professor Mark Ganter for guidance, Ashley Pigott for testing and proof-reading, and Molly Carton for advice.

The MPSCARA was designed, built, and tested in the Solheim Additive Manufacturing Lab at the University of Washington.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Finder

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Standard

Infill:

15%

Notes:

Used 3 perimeters and 4 layers top and bottom. None of the printed parts seemed particularly flimsy using those settings. Used PLA filament.

How to Get the BEST out of your MPSCARA Construction Experience

Depending on your printer, some pieces may be printed with slight lips at the bottoms. In order to save frustration, it is suggested that those are gently filed off, especially on the following pieces:

  • Linear_Bearing_V1.stl
  • Upper_Upper_Arm_V1.stl
  • Forearm_V1.stl

Otherwise, be sure to carefully follow the process plan included in the zip file. Most of the machine is fairly straight-forward, but there are some little tricks in there that help quite a bit.

V1.1

Released on 10/2/2017
Bugfixing
-Accidentally uploaded wrong Linear Bearing file, V1.1 now has the notch mentioned in the instructions. If you already printed the V1 of this part 3 times, you only need to print one of the V1.1s for use on the bearing that connects to the Endstop Clip. The notch helps keep the clip from rotating
-Increased height of the Baseplate file in order to increase stability of the 8mm rods.
-Added more comments to the software to give more detailed error messages.

Quality of Life
-Uploading the major components separately as well as in the combined ZIP file. (Software, STLs, and Marlin are in their own files so you don't need to download the entire new file if you only need to do partial updates.)

10/17/2017
Bugfixing
-Uploaded wrong file for Z Carriage Bottom, new file specifies that the 'Y' wires are on that piece. No structural/functional changes, simply changed for ease of wiring/assembly.

V1

Released on 9/22/2017

comments.text:
Hello Roko11,
Sorry to hear about that, the conversion software still needs some work to be more robust. Currently it's set up as a strict coordinate transformation and doesn't move things around to get the best print location. I'd try moving it around in the build volume so it's close to the origin and in the positive section of the Y axis. If that doesn't work, I'd try shrinking down the model a bit and repeating. The software doesn't know how to deal with things in the negative Y axis just yet, need to learn more about programming to incorporate that.
comments.author: roko11

comments.text: Thanx for the reply. I looked  at the comments below and the solutions did not work out. Also I am Having trouble with the printing . I can home to the stops no problem,BUT I don't understand where 0,0 is from there. Are you looking at the bed from the tower closest to you?  which puts 0,0 at the right of the tower .(endstops) That is completely the opposite of what I am used to with the other builds I have made.(Delta, CoreXY, Prusa derivative) The 0,0 was either center of bed (Delta) of left,front closest to me. In my minds eye the tower would be farthest away from me with 0,0 to my left-front. I tried a dry run with the 25mm test file and it wants to start in a place that does not make sense to me as far as coordinates displayed on screen and actual location. I also switched the X,Y motor and endstop connections which did not change anything. A labeled diagram as to what motor is what(X,Y) and a coordinate map  layout would be good.I am not new to 3d printers but I am new to the SCARA iteration. Your input would be appreciated. Thanx.
comments.author: Williaty

comments.text: Oh yeah, that's fair.  I have the endstops at their current position because that was the simplest to implement hardware-wise, and it required minimal angle-measurements to ensure that it was accurate initially.  The machine interprets that as the (0,0) point, but the conversion software's (0,0) is placed differently.  It should be the offset distance away from the front rail, as specified in the 'settings.txt' file, and 90 degrees counter-clockwise from the endstop positions.  The main issue that you're running into is that the machine's coordinates are completely separate from the standard Cartesian (x,y) coordinates, and without tampering with Marlin (something I'm not good enough with arduinos to do just yet), I don't have an easy way to make the values displayed match up to the physical Cartesian coordinates.  The ones on the readout should be the angles from the endstop to the upper arm as x and the endstop to the lower arm as y.  I'll work on putting together a diagram to show where all the values come from.
comments.author: roko11

BTW, I had trouble with the slide bearings *sticktion", so I subbed them with LM8UU bearings (stacked) on each rod and the mechanism slides much smoother.The 6002 bearings fit nicely. The drive belts I made by counting out the teeth and super-gluing a short piece of belt across the gap while holding it on the large gear to get the spacing right. That works fine while I wait for the endless belts to arrive There is no slack on the long belt.
I will definitely post "I made one" pics when I get farther along. I had a hot end mounted to set Z height and then removed it so I could mount a marker to draw with while I figure out the coordinates issue. I used my CoreXY (DIY FB2020+) to print the parts so I have a printer available to make parts as needed.

comments.text: I have a question or two about aspects of the design that i do not understand. The slit on the fore arm, what is its purpose? As well, why mount the limit switches where you did? My initial approach would to mount them directly on the Z carriage for the upper arm and then Zero the fore arm in the max position. The arm would essentially be folding up on one side.
comments.author: Williaty

comments.text:
The slit is there to assist in getting an accurate measurement of the length of the forearm, as the inner edge of the slit is in line with the center of the axis of rotation of the forearm. The limit switches were mounted that way to ease zeroing, as trying to get an exact angle measurement was proving difficult if one switch was mounted in the elbow, much easier to ensure that the arm is straight.
Hope that helps explain the design process and reasoning behind our decisions!
comments.author: haydenport

comments.author: doigal

comments.text:
Okay, so, funny story... Your math is correct, and it's definitely the right way to go about calculating the steps per degree, and your number should be the one that's used in the firmware.
But, when I was testing it the first time, I had done a math error in some of my calculations. I did the gear ratio backwards, and ended up multiplying the result by ten to get a number that was reasonably correct. It worked perfectly for all my testing, and ended up in the final product as seen in the code. However, when I did a check-up on all the numbers to comment everything for the V1 release, I found the error and fixed it. Upon doing some testing with the new number, it was just slightly off, so I changed it back to the one that I knew worked and left it there.
Definitely give your values a try, but if they lead to discontinuities, try the 57 degrees again. Sorry I can't give you a better answer, but I hope that explains it!
comments.author: doigal

comments.text:
Those are definitely good questions, I'll look into getting you some exact answers. With classes starting up, I don't have as much time as I'd like to devote to this project for now, so I can't promise fast turn around, sorry about that. Here's some preliminary estimates:
1) I'm pretty sure it uses less than one roll/1kg of filament, but I'll do a spreadsheet with filament lengths and print times just to make sure.
2) You can definitely set up a heated bed. You'll need to wire it onto the board and do some edits to the Marlin firmware, but it's certainly possible. There's a decent number of resources online that show wiring diagrams for those if needed, and I can post the Marlin edits if people are interested. As a warning, heated beds will require a higher-amperage power supply, so if you're planning on doing a heated bed make sure you get one of those instead of the one suggested on the BoM. If there's interest, I can put together a 'Heated Bed' zip file with all the recommended changes and instructions.
3) Not sure there, unfortunately. I'd definitely suggest checking out local hardware stores for most of the nuts/bolts/washers, I haven't found anywhere good to go for small quantities of those kinds of fasteners online just yet. Most of them are pretty standard, so you shouldn't have too much trouble getting hold of them.
comments.author: Wooden_Fish

comments.text: Alright. Good answers, thanks!
comments.author: Williaty

comments.text:
Of course, right after I say I'm busy I wind up with free time...
1) It takes approximately 920 g of filament for the whole machine, so one roll ought to cover it. Spreadsheet attached if you're curious. This is using 15% infill, 0.4 mm nozzle, 3 perimeters, and 4 layers top/bottom, which is what we used for our prototype, your mileage may vary.
2) Covered!
3) If you just get everything through Amazon, buying all the machine screws in the 100 packs and whatnot,the total comes out to about $350, not including shipping, those hundred-packs do definitely add up... I'd definitely look at local stores to see if they sell screws à-la-carte, or try to find a 'misc' collection of M3 machine screws, updated spreadsheet with calculations added for your convenience.

comments.text: Hello!  We used two of the thin motors to minimize weight of the Z carriage and to allow for a larger range of Z motion.  You could certainly try with just one of the thin motors for the 'Y' axis (bottom one), but you might need to have an elevated build surface as compared to the mounting base of the printer arm to make sure that the print-head can reach the build area.  I don't think there would be any weight issues caused by the larger motor, but it is a possibility.

comments.author: Williaty

comments.text:
I'm guessing you're having trouble getting the python script to work, right? If you're having trouble with that, make sure that you've got the script saved in the same folder as the two text files and the gcode file you're trying to convert. Attached is the targets.txt file for converting testfile3.gcode and testfile2.g, so you can model your own targets file after that. The two file types (.gcode and .g) are interchangeable, but Python gets confused if you call it testfile3.g but it's saved as testfile3.gcode.
I'm sorry you're running into issues, I'll update my instructions so that people can better understand what I meant. Thank you for bringing up your issue and for your patience, I wish you the best of luck!
comments.author: Expvideo

On the other hand, I'm in Washington too, so maybe I could PM you my number and FaceTime or something.  Sorry, I'm not trying to take all of your time and  treat you like a personal IT guy.  Just excited to see this machine work :). Extremely easy to build and simple design, btw.  I modded the base and made a top for stability, just in case.  Anyway, here's a picture of my build so far.
comments.author: Williaty

comments.text:
Hrm, I sent you a PM to organize a method of communication and trouble-shooting. Attached are some copies of the gcode files we used for testing. The Husky file is intended for pen-drawing, so it wouldn't really do that great with the extruder set in, but if you detach that and just stick a sharpie or other marker in the gripper, it should work fine. Of note, these are customized for my arm lengths, so I can't promise that they'll come out properly scaled on every other printer (Should definitely be pretty close, though, arm section lengths don't really vary that much printer-to-printer).
Other than that, I'm wishing you the best of luck! Definitely looks like you put it together properly! We were doing some testing with a top right before I had to set the project down for a while, so I can't guarantee that it'll work out as you'd prefer. We were running into issues where the top and bottom were slightly differently sized from different printers, and that lead to 'pinching' along the guide rails, so your motors might struggle a little from that, depending on how accurate and consistent your printer is.
comments.author: Expvideo

comments.text: how can you slice the 3d models for this machine design? is cura ok for it?
comments.author: RexLudus

comments.text:
Oh, wait, did you mean slicing models for the machine to print them? Our team tested it with Slic3r, but Cura ought to do the trick so long as you make sure to run the gcode file you sliced in either software through the conversion script (labeled 'Software' in the zip file) to convert it from the standard x-y-z coordinates to the angular coordinates used by the printer, the instructions are available in the Software folder.
Sorry about any confusion caused and the ~2 week wait for the (potential) correction!
comments.author: RexLudus

comments.text: Cura should be okay, I used FlashPrint for our FlashForge printers, but whatever works best for your printer/came from the same company as your printer ought to do the trick.

comments.text: Thank you for the kind words!  Classes are starting up, so we will be slowing down testing and development for a while.  We are still working on nailing down the best settings for printing, and it is likely that additional changes will be implemented before it will be at the top of its game.  In theory, it would have a total print area of approximately 500 square centimeters in an arc shape around the base.  I can't imagine that there will be major changes to the most expensive components of this printer (The stepper motors, controller board, and hotend/extruder).  We haven't started work on the V2 yet, but updates will be coming in as we go through more development and testing!  If you do decide to give building one a shot, please keep us updated on how the construction and testing process goes, we'd love to get some outside perspectives!

comments.text: Thank you!  I can't take all the credit for that aspect of it, the idea of converting the gcode files instead of trying to figure out the SCARA functionality of Marlin was suggested by Professor Ganter.  For the curious, the MPSCARA is programmed to take in angles as an input instead of Cartesian XY coordinates.  It allows for the software running on the Arduino board to be standard off-the-shelf Marlin code, as the complex reverse kinematics calculations are performed on the desktop computer.

description.text:
This is a pair of realistic Handcuffs I designed off of a picture I found on the internet.

They feature a button activated double lock. After activating the double lock turn the key in one direction to unlock the lock then the other direction to unlock the cuff.

Note- With the double lock engaged it is suppose to keep the cuffs from tighten up but with the inherent flex of the bow from being made of plastic it can still tighten if forced hard enough. The bottom button is also a little weak so if it doesn't engage you may have to sand the mating surfaces of the pawl and bolt so they slide easier. This will all depend on your printer and settings.

Mirror these parts in your slicer for second Cuff

  • Handcuff_Casing.STL
  • Handcuff_Casing_Face.STL
  • Handcuff_Lock_Bolt_Button.STL

    Hardware Required for Assembly

  • (10) #4-40 x 1/4" Button Head Screws
  • 1.75 Filament for (3) Pins
  • Fur - optional ;)

    If you have any questions or problems with the files or fitment of the parts just let me know and I will try to fix them.

Remember to tip your waiters designers if you like the service.... thanks for looking.

Layout out of internal parts. Use (3) pieces of 1.75mm Filament x .40" long for the pins. I tapped the holes with a 4-40 tap before inserting the screws. title: Rigid Bed Spring Replacement for Anet or similar

description.text:
Ever since I implemented auto-leveling, The springs on the print bed on my Anet were useless, and only a cause for oscillation at high speed resulting in ghosting. In an effort to illuminate ghosting and other imperfections at high speed, I designed this simple part to eliminate the springs and make a rigid connection with the Bed carriage frame to get rid of any vibration they may have caused.

I have seen a sizable improvement to the print quality in general and at higher printing speeds. You also gain any of the height lost by the length of the springs in your z axis, which isn't tremendous, but can be nice to have.

By just putting the rigid mount the print quality is noticeably better. Ghosting is nearly eliminated. All I can say is that the springs on the bed are an extremely poor design and add a huge margin of vibration to the print surface. My opinion is that adding autolevel just to be able to get rid of the bed springs is a must.

comments.text: thx
comments.author: wildbuffalo

comments.text: I agree with all your comments and myself had a system similsr to thisin my printer. Till the day autolevel fails... That day your z axis will go down and crash against the plate... So no, springs are usefull. If you have ghosting problems may be yor springs are too week, too long or both.
comments.author: Tinchus2009

comments.text: I had the springs all the way tight.  They are garbage. As well, anyone who just hit's print and walks away before making sure the fist layer is going down right is asking for it.  I use a capacitive sensor because I want it to detect the glass.  The capacitive sensor, it is effected by temp change, and when ever you turn off the machine and it cools, you have to re calibrate the sensor. So when ever I  print, I check to see that it is detecting the glass at the right height. Luckily the sensor has an adjustment screw, it takes 10 seconds to set. There for I will never have the problem you speak of because I check it every print.

title: Southern Pride - aka Heritage Not Hate

description.text:
I thought, in the interest of a fair and balanced view as afforded by the First Amendment of the Constitution of the United States of America (at least for the time being), I would provide a counter view to those expressed by the creator of the original piece from which this was "remixed." Rather than simply copy someone else's work, though, I wanted my piece to stand out from the rest.

To that end, this is designed to be printed in multiple colors and assembled like a puzzle. The stars and the stripes are printed in white, the cross is printed in blue and the field is printed in red. For the base, you have two options. First, you can print the version 1 base with the text as one unit, printing in grey first and then swapping to white as soon as the letters being printing. Alternatively, you can print the version 2 base in grey and then print the letters separately in white, reducing them in scale slightly, depending on your printer, to account for the slop needed for a good fit. The letters then press into the base for a recessed look instead.

I will print this when a get a chance, but if anyone else prints it, I would really love to see photos.

Peace....

Printer:

Tevo Tarantula

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Since @csof has already posted a photo of his make using the extruded letters version, I went with the separate letters version. The letters are a snug enough fit that I had to tap them in with a jeweler's brass hammer and once in, they aren't going anywhere.

The pieces seem to fit together just a little bit looser than I had anticipated, although it's not so much to be a problem. Printed as is, you will need to glue everything together. I used E6000 cement. Alternatively, you can scale the blue cross, the red field and the white stripes up by maybe 98 or 99% for a more snug fit.

The stars seem to sit just a smidge lower than expected. The glue on mine holds them a the right level, but you might want to scale the z-axis up just a tad on the white stars for a better fit.

description.text:
Solar film filter holder for AWB OneSky telescope. I was not lucky enough to get the good solar filter film, so I am stuck using several layers of 'space blanket' mylar. This holder should work with any type of solar film though.

Easiest way to install the film is to lay the cover piece down with the ridge up, place the solar film over it and then press the body, ridge up, into the cover. Trim the film and maybe apply a little bit of glue to keep everything together, though the interference fit 'should' be enough. The ridge of the body should slide into the hole at the top of the scope.

description.text:
I've added a 2 part body that helps with the curling I was getting with the narrow base of the single piece. For me, the gun prints best with a small brim but the stand seem to be OK as long as bed adhesion is good. Because the body of the gun is vertical, I got much better results when printing slower.

Depending on what scale game you are playing, this can be many different things. It can be AA, AT, heavy mg, light mg, etc. In the 15mm - 28mm scales this is taller than the characters so it makes a nice air or vehicle defense weapon. In the second picture you see this model next to my Sfi Fi Slug Thrower https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2483959 and a 15mm and 28mm character from dutchmogul. The gun itself is about 60mm from the tip of the barrel to the rear of the receiver.

I had to do some clean up to get all the pieces to snap together. The stand was fine as well as the barrels, but the rear end cap needed to be trimmed a little and the brim around the top optical sight had to be trimmed a little. Make sure the ball joints for the stand legs are clean. This will help them insert easier and move more freely.

The stand is separate because you might want to use it for something else. If you use it in your own model, please let me know. I'd love to see how you use it. As always, anything original that I publish here can be used as you see fit - even selling them. It's my way of giving back to the community that's given so much to me. However, if you end up making money using it, consider tipping me and contributing to my filament bill.

Printer:

Tronxy P802MA

No

15%

print_settings.Notes:: Only the gate needs to be printed with supports.

description.text:
This is a horse stable with a functional swinging gate. The completed stable consists of seven pieces. You need to print two roofs and two sides, the back, the support for the gate, the gate and the detailed wooden floor. The gate is tight in the support to allow easy movement, but it is tight enough to remain where you place it. You may need to clean the holes out of the gate support depending on the accuracy of your printer. It is purposely made a little tight.
Only the gate needs to be printed with supports. You superglue all the parts together to finish the project. The floor has very detailed wood slats that could also be used for other building or just for a tile as well. Textured roof as well as detailed in the wood sides and back.

title: STC-1000 Temperature Control Box  (no supports needed)

description.text:
I made a stc-1000 box that prints without supports. I made this for my heated printer enclosure, but there are many uses for these controllers. I hope this fits your needs.

The lid is attached to the base via m3 screws with nuts that are inserted into the base part. There are cable tie slots on the base where individual wires can be tied down before being sandwiched between the lid and the base.

You will need to split the stl and flip the lid part so that both parts have the ends of the box on the bed. It will then be good to go.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Split and flip the lid.

title: Nimble Gnu - System to Adapt the Zesty Nimble Extruder to a Prometheus V2 Hotend Mounted to a SeeMeCNC Balljoint Effector Platform with Accelerometer Probe PCB

description.text:
Overview:

A system to adapt the Zesty Technology Remote Direct Drive Extruder to a Prometheus V2 Hotend via a SeeMeCNC Accelerometer Probe PCB and Ball Joint Effector Platform. Straps are used to retain the whip connector and there are a pair of 3mm auxiliary holes at each pillar for mounting items such as Berd Air System tubing or a probe etc.

The mounting system makes use of the Nimble to firmly seat the PTFE tubing in the bottom of the hotend barrel. Consequently, "setting" the PTC fitting in the hot end is not necessary which avoids narrowing the PTFE lumen at this point.

If you are interested in a Nimble-Prometheus-Ball Joint Platform setup without the Accelerometer please leave a comment and i will make an option for that sooner than later. In the interim, you could use this system without the Accelerometer PCB provided you place a little spacer between the bottom of the Guide Bushing and the top of the Prometheus to make up the vertical height (~1.7mm) of the absent board.

Required Parts:

  • M4 x 12 to 16mm button head or socket head cap screws to mount effector platform. QTY 3.
    Note: Button heads are recommended if using standard Rostock Max v2 fan shrouds.
  • M4 x 25mm button head or socket head cap screws to secure the Cap. QTY 3.
  • M3 x 6 to 10mm screws to affix the accelerometer board. QTY 3.
    Note: Nylon recommended to avoid shorting LED pads.
  • ~ 60mm length of 4mm OD x 1.8 to 2.0mm ID PTFE tubing.

Recommended Tools:

  • M4 x 0.7 Tap
  • M3 x 0.5 Tap
  • 4mm(#21) Drill - to size 4mm holes in Cap, Clamp Plate and Centre Plate
  • 3.3mm (#30) Drill to size holes for tapping the M4 threads in the Stand Off
  • 3mm (#31) Drill to size 3mm holes in Cap and Clamp Plate
  • 2.4mm (3/32) Drill to clean out holes for tapping the accelerometer Clamp Plate
  • Drill bits +/- 4mm(#21) to size Guide Bushing bore to suit your PTFE tube size
  • 1/2" half round file for fine tuning holes and slots to fit hot end
  • A half inch or similar half round file for finishing and sizing
  • Sharp knife or razor to trim PTFE tubing
  • Metal Saw to cut M3 Bolt
  • Variable Speed Hand Drill Motor
  • A small jewelers screw driver or blunt probe to install the straps.
  • Hex driver (Allen) keys to suit your selected fasteners.
  • Method of measuring hot end barrel depth

Prometheus Mount

Stand Off Sizing

  • Decide if you will assemble the platform with the ball joint "barbells" on the bottom or top. Bottom orientation will allow shorter (and presumably stiffer) stand offs for a given amount of protrusion below the axis but will place the fan shrouds closer to the bed surface.
  • For the nozzle size and nut-nozzle zone setup of your Prometheus, decide how much protrusion below the platform you want.
    Note: Leave enough clearance for the fan shrouds and ball end arms to clear the bed clips!!
  • For the arrangement determined above, measure the distance from the top of the platform to the upper edge of the lower groove of the hot-end. This distance (in mm) with be the size/filename of the Stand Off model.

Components to Print: Prometheus Mount

  • one of the Standoffs_XXmm from the StandOffs_32_55mm.zip file
  • Centre_Plate_1
  • Nimble_Gnu_Clamp_Plate_71210_Accel_Prometheus
    Note: ABS recommended for these three parts for ease of post print sizing and natural lubricity for sliding into hotend grooves.

Assembly Instructions: Prometheus Mount

Considerations for assembling the Accelerometer PCB and Prometheus Hotend
Note that the arrangement of the heater block wiring to the accelerometer plate is such that the wires run up the left side of the hotend when looking down on it from the top and with the fan positioned away from you. See the various photos. The orientation of the cap to accelerometer PCB and the Nimble to the cap is fixed as also is the Clamp Plate to the accelerometer PCB. In order to have the breech block oriented to the front of the machine and the fan positioned towards the back (Z tower), the orientation shown in the photos must be followed. Other orientations may be possible by mirroring the Cap and/or the Clamp Plate before slicing.

  • When preparing to solder the fan connector headers avoid "pinching" the the pins together for retention. One of the heater wires will likely want to run right between them.
  • Providing a little (~1cm) slack in the heater and thermistor wires will allow disassembly of the Hotend without undue strain on them.
  • Through drill the large holes in the Clamp and Centre Plates ONLY to 4mm.
  • Through drill the holes in the Standoff to 3.3mm to size them for tapping.
  • Tap holes in Standoff from each end with the M4 tap.
    Note: Tap deep enough ensure that the M4 bolts will fully seat.
  • Through drill the small holes in the Clamp Plate to 2.4mm to size them for tapping.
  • Tap the small holes in the Clamp Plate with the M3 tap.
  • Ensure upper and lower surfaces of the the plates are free of swarf from drilling and tapping.
  • Relieve edges and finish slots in the Clamp Plate and Standoff to 12mm and 16mm and the centre hole of the Centre Plate to 16mm.
    Note: Fit of the Standoff and Clamp Plate into hot-end grooves should be snug but ensure that the Hotend seats fully into slots and that no more than a gentle squeeze is required to bring the bolt holes into alignment.

  • Slide and fully seat the Standoff into the lower groove of the hotend.

  • Place the Centre Plate over the top of the Hotend and onto the Clamp Plate.

  • Clock the Clamp Plate as shown to accommodate LED, thermistor and fan wiring.
  • Slide and fully seat the Clamp Plate into upper groove of Hotend.

Note: It is not necessary to "seat" the PTC connector, it can be left loose. The Nimble will hold the PTFE tube firmly at the bottom of the Hotend barrel.

  • Ensure Accelerometer PCB fits flatly and easily into the recess in the Clamp Plate.
  • Temporarily install 4mm x 25mm screws through top of Clamp Plate into Standoff to ensure alignment of Clamp Plate.
  • Then firmly snug down 3mm screws to secure Accelerometer PCB.
  • Ensure soldered wires do not protrude more than 2mm above the PCB.
  • Arrange fan wires as shown in order to clear Cap.

Nimble Adapter

Components to Print: Nimble Adapter

  • Nimble_Gnu_Cap_Prometheus_71210_Accel_Rev1
    Notes:
    PETG is recommended for strength of thin sections and thread robustness.
    Best printed upside down (as shown in stl model).
    Support for the countersink holes is recommended
    Set xy support clearance to at least 0.3mm to maintain countersink clearance for the screw heads.
  • Guide_Bushing_Prometheus_Rev1
    Note: ABS recommended for ease of post print sizing and natural lubricity for passing PTFE tubing.
  • Strap QTY 2
    Note: TPU (NinjaFlex) recommended - you will likely get a much better result after installing the Nimble!

Assembly Instructions: Nimble Adapter

  • Trim ONE of the 40mm bolts that came with the Nimble to 35-37mm.
  • Through drill the large holes in the Cap to 4mm and ensure bolt heads fit freely in the countersinks.
  • Through drill the small holes in the Cap to 2.4mm to size them for tapping.
  • Tap the small holes in the Cap with the M3 tap.
  • Ensure all surfaces are free of swarf from drilling and tapping and that the centre hole of the cap is free of protrusions.
  • Square one end of the PTFE tube and chamfer the OD slightly.
    Note: Be sure to thoroughly clean the PTFE tubing of any fragments after cutting or shaping it. You do not want discover any unmelted shards in the tip of a small nozzle because by the time you excavate them, your sense of humor will be long gone...
  • Drill out the bore of the guide bushing so that your PTFE tube passes smoothly through it with a little force. The PTFE tubing should NOT be loose in the Guide Bushing.
  • Size the OD of the Guide Bushing so that it passes just freely through the centre hole of the cap.
    Note: You may want to employ the poor person's lathe for this purpose.

  • Measure the depth of the barrel in the hot end and the length of the PTFE tube.
  • Insert the squared and tapered end of the PTFE tube into the hot end barrel and seat it firmly.
  • Measure amount of PTFE tube protruding and verify tube is fully seated in the bottom of the Hotend barrel.
  • Install the two straps (can be done once Hotend mounted in printer so these could be your first print).
    Note: Judicious use of a small screw driver and a fingernail will avoid bloodletting and savagery.

  • Install the cap with the M4 x 25mm bolts.
  • Place the Guide Bushing over the PTFE tubing and seat it on top of the hot end.
  • Set the Groove Mount Adapter on top of the Guide Bushing. It should sit flat against the top of the Cap. Shorten the Guide Bushing from the Bottom if necessary.
  • The height of the top of the Guide Bushing should be just below the height of the rear locking tang (drive end) of the Groove Mount Adapter.
  • The smaller diameter "pin" of the Guide Bushing should fit snugly into the upper part of the Groove Mount Adapter.

  • While firmly pressing the PTFE tube into the bottom of the Hotend barrel , trim the PTFE tubing so that it slightly protrudes above the top of the Guide Bushing (0.3mm or about the width of a razor blade).
  • Mount the Nimble. Use the 40mm bolt with the Sleeve Clamp (or a 3mm spacer for fit testing without the drive cable) to avoid damaging the Accelerometer PCB.

  • Gentle tightening of the Nimble Mounting bolts should cause the Nimble to seat squarely on the Groove Mount Adapter and the entire body of the Nimble should seat squarely on the top of the Cap.
  • The PTFE tube should contact the bottom of the filament guide groove on centre without distortion. Re-trim the PTFE tube if necessary.
    Note: If you cut it twice and it is "still to short", START AGAIN with a new piece of tubing. You do not want the PTFE tube to be able to move vertically re the dread filament jam at the bottom of the barrel...

  • Once satisfied with the fit, snug down the Nimble mounting bolts.
  • Install Hotend in printer, strap down the whip.

  • Remember to revisit your slicer retraction settings. It is a whole new world without the Bowden tube.

print_settings.Notes:: The larger version is for those lanyards that have very thick ribbons, or those who need to take up a lot of slack.

title: Lanyard Lifter - Conference badge height adjuster

description.text:
Does your conference badge dangle in your lap when you sit? Do does your badge hang so low that people must stare at your navel (or worse, lower) to read your name?

This gadget slips over your lanyard ribbons and winds up excess length, allowing you to shorten the lanyard, but still easily take your lanyard off over your head (the device will unwind with a gentle pull).

Safer than tying a knot, and more socially acceptable than slapping crotch-gazers!

How to assemble:

Place both the ribbons of your lanyard through the slot in the the spindle.

Slide the outer shell over the spindle and lanyard, passing the lanyard ribbons through the slots in the shell.

Fit the cap over the end of the spindle, and turn it 1/4 turn to lock.

Wind the knob to take up excess lanyard length.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

100%

Notes:

New design requires no support. The spindle knob is now a knurled cylinder that is self-supporting.

The STL files are for a small version and a large version. You only need three parts (all small, or all large). You can generate other sizes by editing the SCAD file.

The larger version is for those lanyards that have very thick ribbons, or those who need to take up a lot of slack.

comments.text: Redesigned for no-support printing, and now has the ability to add text on the shell.

description.text:
This is still a work in progress, I've only printed a very small prototype to test my changes to the design. My goal is to have it in at least two halves that can be broken down and stack to take up less room in the kitchen. To that end I've split the original in half and added a simple latch. If two are printed they should fit into each other. This worked at 25% scale, still to be tested at full size.

More to follow.

UPDATE: Aplha deleted. I printed it full size and it has some major flaws that need fixing. (see pics)

UPDATE 2: Just uploaded the 'Beta' version, it has tweaked dimensions for the latch system that should make it a better fit. - This is beta in untested as of yet.

UPDATE 2a: Tested the beta, it's better, but not good enough yet. Moving to Gamma.

UPDATE 3: Untested Gamma version uploaded. More tweaks to connection bits.

UPDATE 4: Gamma tested, a little loose, Delta version added, untested.

description.text: This file is 1/2 of a massage ball, designed in Fusion 360. I designed it for self-applied trigger point massage. Print twice, then connect the two halves using either heat, epoxy, or by adding your own connectors. This ball is designed to be large enough to provide pressure to the back, even when sitting against softer cushions. The first version of this ball used an insert and twist lock pattern, but I removed it because of how weak the joints were. In my experience, heat fusion has been enough to keep the parts together.

Printer:

Monoprice Maker Select V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

=<0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Average speed works fine for the lower half, but once the spikes start finishing as independent circles, consider lowering the print speed for better quality spikes.

title: Tevo Black Widow Titan Extruder/Volcano Hotend/BLTouch Mount Assembly

description.text:
CURRENTLY BEING TESTED. UPLOADED FOR A PRINT REQUEST ONLY

This is a revised version of the factory Tevo Titan Extruder Kit mount that caters for the E3D Volcano Hotend. This assembly also includes a revised mount for the ANTCLABS BLTouch, which has been modified to cater for the height and Y-axis position of the Titan/Volcano assembly.

If you aren't using a BLTouch, this extruder mount will still work for the Titan/Volcano assembly.

Revised Specifications and Strength

The factory Tevo Black Widow Titan Extruder Kit mount is 2mm thick. This revised edition is 3mm thick for better rigidity and strength.

The factory mount includes 4mm bolt slots, but the X-axis gantry has 5mm holes. This revised edition includes measured and fixed 5mm bolt holes.

The factory mount has a solid backing plate, which doesn't allow the X-axis belt mount bolts to be removed from the gantry. This revised edition includes a 20mm slot in the mount backing plate that allows access to the belt mount bolts after the extruder stepper motor is removed.

The factory mount doesn't include clearance for the X-axis gantry lower V-wheel nut. This revised edition has a cutaway to allow space for both the nut and a socket tool.

The factory mount doesn't include clearance for the lower forward bolt securing the Titan extruder case to the extruder housing. The bolt protrudes the housing and into the factory mount, causing it to flex under tension. This revised edition has a cutaway to allow space for the bolt, making it unnecessary to file the bolt down.

Benefits of the Titan Assembly
The original factory Tevo Black Widow extruder is more than twice as heavy as the lightweight Tevo Titan extruder kit. The original includes a large stepper motor, stainless steel gearbox, and an aluminium extruder, whereas the Titan uses a stepper motor less than half the size, and plastic extruder.

The original also extends past the X-axis gantry plate, which prevents the printer from using the full reach of the bed's print space. The Titan reduces the extruder footprint to fit within the confines of the gantry plate, allowing maximum use of the print bed.

title: Cheap Eclipse / Christmas Glasses Lens Adapter

description.text:
Disclaimer: If you blow up your device or eyes using this cap I'm not accountable for any loss or damage. Please remember the staring at or pointing cameras at the sun is dangerous.

I created a lens cap holder for my American Paper Optics Solar Eclipse Glasses. This should allow me to use my super cheap telescopic lens to take pictures of the solar eclipse.

I'm using the 12x Zoom Telephoto lens that came from the kit from Apexel on Amazon;
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01N1INMPI

I looked at a few of the other cheap 12x Zoom Telephoto clip on lenses from Amazon and I think a lot of them are the same telephoto lense brand, as they have the red "trim" with the same markings. The inside diameter of the cap is 35mm, so if your lens is that size it should work.

I'm using Eclipse Glasses from APO (the width is 37mm x ..5mm depth);
https://www.eclipseglasses.com/collections/eclipse-glasses-stock/products/stock-eclipse-glasses

American Paper Optic paper glasses are one of the most popular brands. Companies like Lowes, Home Depot, Kroger etc are/were selling them. Check inside the arm and they should say the manufacture. Really any glasses that are equal or less them 37mm x 1mm should be fine.

Edit: Video of me testing the Camera with the lens adapter. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NqfqABAV-60

Edit 2: American Paper Optics also sells paper glasses for Christmas that ate the same width as the eclipse frames, so the lense adapter works for those too. They sell them in Lowe's and Home Depot and they make lights look like different Christmas items. I've included an image of the star and raindeer glasses.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

My support pillar resolution is 1mm for the gap where the glasses slid into the cap.

I used an X-acto knife to get out the supports, but you could use a jewelers flat tip or something else little small and strong to remove them. I would suggest you make sure the gap is as smooth as possible before you slide your glasses through them, because you don't want the lenses to rip or tear.

title: Drybox Right Angle Filament Guide
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I printed the parts for two Dry Boxes from Thingiverse item http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1999478. I wanted to stack the two Dry Boxes and put 8 rolls in each box, so I mounted the grommets on the end of the box.

However, the printer was on a table above the drybox, and there was too much friction when my printer was pulling the filament 90 degrees to the filament grommets, so I built this guide to hold a bearing to make the transition with very little friction.

Assembly,

just pop a 608 bearing (standard roller skate bearing) into the assembly, and an 16mm M3 machine screw and nut. Fit it over the printed DryBox Grommet, and Robert's your Mom's Brother*, your filament can do a 90 degree without much friction.

* Bob's your Uncle

I'm a proud member of the Barrie Wireless Amateur eXperimenters (WAX) group, where we socialize and build lots of Amateur Radio oriented projects.
WAX Group Website
WAX Group Blog

description.text:
Summary

Basic shell case for iPhone 6. Tested to fit on real phone. 50 mils thick on all sides, with openings for sleep and volume controls. Blank back so feel free to customize. Comments appreciated.
UPDATE:
v3: Rounded corners for better aesthetics and less pant-snaggin (shown in bronzefill).
v2: Increased width of case by 20 mils. Phone now fits in the case more easily while still remaining snug.
SLDPRT: I've uploaded the SolidWorks file by request. It was made in SolidWorks 2013.

Instructions

I printed it at 100% scale in PLA on a MendelMax 1.5. It was thin enough such that there were no infill layers generated. Not sure how the case would work if there were an infill layer. It fits great without any cracking. The part was designed in SolidWorks.

print_settings.Notes:: I have a titan extruder clone. Make sure your printer can handle flex filaments
print_settings.Printer:: GeeeTech Prusa i3 Acrylic Pro B

title: American Made 5 Gallon Carboy Air Lock plug Bung - Brewing

description.text:
I found a really affordable PETE (BPA Free) 5 gallon carboy on amazon. The neck though is a bit bigger than a conventional 5 gallon carboy. I designed a bung that would fit. I printed it in "SAINSMART TPU Flexible Filament ": http://a.co/28lpzFx . The flex filament makes it more like the normal bungs. A hard filament most likely wouldn't fit correctly but if anyone gets it to work post in comments.

Update:
Normally with my printer tolerance I need to make items .5mm smaller otherwise my print would be too big. I am new to flex filament. The first couple I printed came out smaller then the stl design. I was perplexed. I made a couple changes, however, if you have issues you can edit the tinkercad. The short one is much bigger to make up for the shrinking. It's very snug fit which is hopefuly a good seal. I'll report back.

Amazon link for carboy: http://a.co/55XgoEJ
If you need to modify: https://tinkercad.com/things/2f9TWXmLMUZ

Enjoy :)

This is a cold block for -20oC freezer storage to keep enzymes and other biochemistry reagents cold while they are handled at the lab bench.

Printer Brand:

Zortrax

Printer:

Zortrax M200

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.14mm

Infill:

Low

Notes:

Print the cap and the cold block upside down. Print the plug flat.
I used Z-HIPS Natural White filament, as it is solvent resistant and tough.

Paint one side of the plug and the inside of the coldblock with epoxy glue from the hardware store (e.g. Araldite Rapid). Ensure the coating of epoxy has no gaps, as this coating prevents the fill liquid (50% isopropanol in water) from leaking. Leave the epoxy coated parts for 24h to cure at room temperature.

Fill the inside of the cold block with room temperature 50% isopropanol in water. Only fill up to 5mm below the inside lip of the cold block where the plug will sit. Do not let the solution splash up onto the lip where the plug will be glued. Coat the lip with more epoxy glue. Use enough to ensure the gap between the plug and coldblock is filled. Insert the plug such that it sits on the lip and has a solid rim of epoxy glue around it, which will hold the liquid inside. Do not move the block for 24h while the glue cures.

comments.text:
Thank you for having interest in new design.
OK, this spacer has never fell out accidentally during 3 all-day airsoft games.
I don't say 'its incredible holding power keeps the position at any time', but it is enough for practical use.
Its overhang is sandwiched by barrel and trunnion, then the alignment is supported by the chamber. This fixation method achieves both 'snap-fit' style and fall-out-proof.
If anxiety, you can use the traditional design (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1995791).

title: Recoil Line Mount for Delta Printer

description.text:
This is a mount which I use for attaching a recoil line (ID card belt clip type) to one of the crossbars at the top of my Delta printer, so that I can use the recoil line to hold the hotend cable bundle and the bowden tube above the print level and out of the way of prints.

I mount this to the 2020 extrusion using an M4 bolt and a T-nuit.

The belt clip for the recoil line fits through the hole in the back of the mount, and the raised bar at the broad end fits into the 6mm center channel in the extrusion for stability.

title: CTC i3 Clone X/Y axis belt pulley idler

description.text:
My cheap e-bay i3 clone broke it's X-axis belt pulley holder.
I couldn't find a already made replacement part that fitted so I decided to try to draw it up in Rhino.

The holes for the bearings are ø8mm with no play and are intended to possible be drilled for exact match. Same with the long M3 bolt for belt tension.

The bearings for this thing is MF 85 ZZ.

This is the result, it's not yet printed so consider it a work in progress.

comments.text: Now my glued idler broke again so I decided to try my printed things. Drilling the holes for the bearing with an 8mm drill worked just perfect and the fitted just fine, however the distance between the sides are too narrow unless the bearings flanges are counter sunked into the sides which I noticed after the disassembly of the part. I had to file it down to make it run smooth.

title: Macbook Air Stand printed or Acrylic Bent laptop notebook holder openscad parametric support mac book

description.text:
This Macbook Air Stand can be printed or it can be made bending a 12" x 20" (~ 30cm x 51cm) shape of Acrylic to hold laptops, notebooks and tablets.  
I designed it to hold my MacBook AIr 13" because I've used my laptop while lying in bed with it resting on my chest and leg. The bent corners was made the protect my chest of very slim corners of the Macbook Air usually hurts my chest.  
This holder was made with openscad parametric cad and it can be changed, but some manual adjusts should be needed for different sizes and angles of inclination.

This Macbook Air Stand can be printed or it can be made bending a 12" x 20" (~ 30cm x 51cm) shape of Acrylic to hold laptops, notebooks and tablets.  
To be printed it use a plate of 161,2mm x 141,39 and 2 (two) pieces have to be printed to hold correct hold the notebook.  
Another option is it be made with a shape of acrylic just bending one shape of 12" x 20" (~ 30cm x 51cm). One shape of plastic acrylic with A3 size can be used, but the A3 size is 29,7cm x 42cm and you can reduce the size of horizontal base without problem.  
If you print or bent acrylic to make it, please share some pictures! I will appreciate a lot.

Print the body and wings in natural.

Do a barrel roll.

Uses four 608 bearings

This is a ball-and-stick model of benzene molecule. As you can see, the carbon atoms (black) are linked using two connections which represent the chemical bonds. It was printed with a gypsum powder printer at the Technical University of Berlin during a summer course.

I designed it like this in order to better represent the ressonance effect and also to make it less fragile since gypsum model this thin will easily break if you're not careful.

The size of atoms and the distance between them take into account chemistry bond theory. The scale is approximately 250.000.000 : 1.
After the print is done, we have to clean the remaining powder from its surface and then infuse it with resin in order to make it less fragile.
I used Autodesk Inventor for modelling and Autodesk Nettfabb to check if the part was printable.

comments.text: Shouldn't benzene have alternating single/double bonds? Otherwise the carbons have 5 bonds each.
comments.author: Jackflef

comments.text: Yes, you're right. In chemistry textbooks you'll find two possible isomers for the benzene molecule, and it can also be represented with a circle inside the hexagon aromatic ring.

title: Iphone Stereoscope
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Meant to be used with an iPhone app which allows stereoscopic usage from the camera, but could be used with any stereoscopic app. Right now our app is in the publishing process, so expect a link to it in about a month or so, but for now check out these my3D apps my favorite one (a virtual underwater shark tank) is
https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/my3d-360-sharks/id428087225?mt=8 the rest can be found at
https://itunes.apple.com/us/artist/hasbro-inc./id408889710

If all 4 parts are printed on high resolutions their tolerances should such that they piece together nicely. Also they are in parts to minimize support areas, and reduce time for individual prints. As far as the eye piece, there is a space for lenses to be dropped in. These are NEEDED if you want your eyes to focus on the screen in the proper way and we've built a few now and have the focal length properly adjusted to a 150mm focal length lens, and the eyepiece fits a 35mm diameter lense. We SCOURED the web and found some cheap ones here:
http://www.anchoroptics.com/catalog/product.cfm?id=152&s=focal_length&d=d check 'em out and hope you enjoy.

description.text:
This is a mount for a Raspberry Pi 1 B in a Tek Berry housing, for mounting it on the left or right side on top of a Geeetech Prusa i3 Pro X. Other printers might work as well.
The Pi is easy accessible and no other part of the printer needs to be removed for mounting the holder or the Pi.

Printer:

Geeetech i3 pro x

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed in about one hour.

Final words

Designed in one afternoon with Fusion 360 (was a real joy), after many cumbersome tries and rage quits with other CAD modeling software.

The print itself consists of two parts: one mounting plate and an adjustable clamp.

For the final assembly you will need five screws, four washers and five hex nuts.

Feel free to modify the 3D modell to fit your needs.

A mark 2 Version with improved clamps for less wiggle is included.
