description.text:
(Deutsche Beschreibung unten)

This is a case for the Calliope mini one-board-computer planned to be used in German primary schools. ( http://calliope.cc/en )

I wanted a case that can stay on the Calliope permanently, but leave the pads etc. exposed for experimenting.

Its currently basically done, but there are some todos:

  • add hole above the reset switch
  • maybe rework the peg/hole thing used to hold the 2 halves together.

Hier ist eine Hülle für den Calliope mini Ein-Platinen-Computer, der ab 2017 als Pilotprojekt in deutschen Grundschulen eingesetzt werden soll. ( http://calliope.cc/ )

Ich wollte eine Hüllle die Zugriff auf Kontaktflächen etc. lässt, aber nicht ständig abgenommen werden muss.

Das Model ist soweit fertig, und funktioniert, aber es gibt noch ein paar Dinge auf der ToDo Liste:

  • Ein Loch für einfacheren zugang zum Reset-Knopf
  • Vielleicht ein anderer Mechanismus um die beiden Hälften zusammen zu halten.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

i3 MK2 MMU

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Notes:

For a standard print, you only need main_upper_body.stl and calliope_bottom.stl

You need to flip the calliope_top.stl 180 degrees for printing without supports and for a smooth surface finish.

The main_upper_body_with_letters.stl has the button and logo embossed into the surface, usefull for printing the first 2 layers with a different color than the rest of the top, to get a multicolor effect on the lettering, or to fill it later with color by hand.

This Model includes optional files for multicolor prints:

  • letter_b.stl, lettter_a.stl, logo.stl - Button lettering and Logo
  • transparent_covers_single.stl - Single transparent cover for RGB led
  • transparent_covers.stl - Transparent covers for led matrix

If you have a dual or more material printer, you can add the A/B/logo/cover files as modifier meshes to the calliope_top.stl in your slicer, and assign different colors/extruders to them.
The transparent covers are meant to be printed in transparent or translucent plastic, see picture.
(tested in Slic3r Prusa Edition, printed with Prusa MK2 with MMU)

Für einen normalen 3d-Drucker werden nur main_upper_body.stl und calliope_bottom.stl gebraucht.
Das main_upper_body.stl Model muss vor dem Druck um 180 Grad gedreht werden, um eine glatte Oberfläche zu bekommen, und da ansonsten unnötiges Support-Material benutzt werden müsste.

Die Datei main_upper_body_with_letters.stl enthällt die Beschriftung als "Gravur" und eignet sich gut um die ersten beiden Layer mit einer anderen Farbe zu drucken als den Rest. das gibt der Schrift eine andere Farbe als der Oberfläche, ohne das man einen Multimaterial Drucker haben muss.
Oder man füllt die Gravur nach dem Druck von hand mit Farbe (Geschmolzene Wachsmalstifte z.b.)

Dieses Model beinhaltet optionale STLs für multicolor/mutimaterial Drucker:

  • letter_b.stl, lettter_a.stl, logo.stl - Button lettering und Logo
  • transparent_covers_single.stl - transparentes cover für RGB led
  • transparent_covers.stl - transparentes cover für led matrix

Die A/B/logo Dateien können im Slicer als "modifier meshes" verwendet werden, und diesen können dann verschiedene Farben zugeordnet werden.

Die 'transparent_cover*' dateien sind zum Druck mit transparentem Plastik gedacht, und dienen als Diffusor für die Leds.

(getested in Slic3r Prusa Edition, gedruckt mit Prusa MK2 mit MMU)

Join case halves

To get the top and bottom half to merge well, you might have to sand the "pegs" or drill out the holes a little.

I had to use a file on 2 pegs to get them to fit, but don't overdo it, the pegs need to be stuck inside the holes at least a little.

Damit die beiden Hälften zusammenpassen, müssen gegebenenfalls die "Stecker" oder die Löcher angepasst werden.

In meinem fall musste ich zwei "Stecker" mit leicht einer Feile bearbeiten. Schmirgelpapier wird auch funktionieren, oder das Loch mit einem Bohrer leicht weiten.
Die Stecker sollten fest in den Löchern halten, damit der Deckel nicht abfallen kann.
Calliope mini This is a case for the Calliope mini one-board-computer planned to be used in German primary schools. ( http://calliope.cc/en )
This is only a case for the Calliope mini, and not a lesson.

title: Toyota Corolla (2004) Air Vent Blade
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is for a 13 years old Corolla. 2 blades from an air vent were broken.

Important when printing : Do not use supports. The model includes very small supports for each of the 3 cylindric axes (the cylindric parts that must be inserted inside the vent).

So take care

  • to print no more than 0.1 mm layer height for the supports to print correctly.
  • if you want to rotate the model into your slicer, supports must be on contact with the bed

After printing, remove the 3 small supports using a razor blade.

I printed this using M-ABS (kind of ABS) because it's a little bit more flexible than PLA so this makes it easier to insert the blades into the vent. But PLA should work.
If necessary, after printing, sanding a little bit around the cylinders can help.

Picture : the new blades are number 3 & 4 starting from the top of the vent.

Comments welcome

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

100

Notes:

M-ABS - nozzle (0.4 mm) 245 °C - Bed 90 °C
Layer height 0.1 mm (important) - First layer 0.1 mm (important)
40 mm/s - Brim 15 (prevent warping)

Cut the supports

After printing, cut the (very small) supports under the 3 cylinders using a razor blade. Sand them a little bit if necessary

Buy small fingers

... in order to insert the blades into the vent correctly :-)
Sketchup Make 2017

title: CNC Mill Updated parts for 100x20mm aluminium profile

description.text:
I remodelled all the parts from this CNC router to fit 100x20mm aluminium.
the designer of this CNC used 100x18mm that is impossible to get here in my country.
after google it, i saw it's mainly sold in France.

I only uploaded the the remodelled parts that are needed. rest can be downloaded from the main designer. you can keep his build instructions, nothing has changed in size.

Update,
I printed all the parts, all sizes fit, but I suggest to make the Threaded rod M8 768mm 4mm longer to compensate the extra 2mm on both side.
I didn't do it, and it still fit but get's a bit tight.

Also X and Z nut, the once I got were 14mm, So I changed those 2 models to fit 14mm nuts. I've added those 2 models as well

Cheers

remixed_from.title: Greg's Wade reloaded - Guidler, Tilt Screws, Fishbone Gears

description.text:
The perfect mate for a NEMA 14 Wallace printer. A nema 14 version of the Greg's Wade reloaded - Guidler, Tilt Screws, Fishbone Gears. Set to 1.75mm filament, grovemount for makergear hot end, and uses the fishbone Gears from
was:http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:7993 correction:http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:18379 Inspired by Xendi in the Wallace thread.

print tested with 0.24 layer height.
1.75mm filament
9/47 fishbone gears
grovemount for Makergear hot end with 50mm Use 2 long M4 screws with washer-spring-washer and they will snap on and off the idler without much problem. I had a 1" spring that I cut in half and it works great. The motor runs just a bit hotter than I like but you can touch it without getting burned at printing speeds of 30, 60, and 65 it skipped steps above that while pulling on a 2kg reel of filament so I run it at 60 for now. If you re-render from Source you will need to fix the .stl with netfabb before you skein and print it.

comments.text:
Ok, this little extruder has been running off an on for a good while on the all Nema14 Reprap Wallice I designed it for. But the Nema14 motor I have is barely able to keep up with faster printing speeds and gets very hot. If I adjust down the amperage so it isn't too hot to touch it then looses steps anytime the filament snags or has to pull hard from a heavy spool. Next time I would go with a higher oz/in motor.
On the bright side the prints it produces are very good quality.

description.text:
This thing is a 3D sculpture of the famous painting "Le viol" from 1934 by Belgian artist Rene Magritte.
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ren%C3%A9_Magritte I made it as an exercice to practice with mixing meshes in Meshmixer and for sculpting in Sculptris.
It is intended to be printed but I didn't have the time yet. Updated : I have made a second version that IMHO is closer to Magritte's original artwork. I slightly turned the head on the right and refined the hair to better fit the painting. For more information about this thing, please visit http://www.reppersdelight.spacymen.com/index.php/post/2014/02/12/Having-fun-with-Meshmixer-and-Sculptris Edited : I finally found the time to print it and the sculpture can stand by itself which is a good point !

You may print it either in ABS or PLA.
Use something like 2 or 3 shells and about 30% infill.
You can also print it hollow if you prefer. If you do print it I will be glad to see the result. Cheers !

print_settings.Notes:: Support only needed for "back.stl". Nozzle 0.4mm

description.text:
Designed from the ground up for 3D printing BoBo Clock makes for a nice little companion at your desk or bedside table.
 
You can get the quartz movement for the clock here. If you buy from another place just make sure that the dimensions are correct. The shaft diameters are especially important since the clock-hands are attached through press fit.

 

Assembly

The assembly can be done in 2 minutes without using any screws or glue.

Step 1

The first step is to attach the legs to the back. This is done by inserting each leg, then twisting it 90 degrees to lock it in place.

 

Step 2

Now insert the shaft of the clock movement into the front, tightening it into place using the included nut.

Step 3

Now attach the hour and minute hand onto the shaft. Most likely the holes will be too small due to deformation during printing. To solve for this just use a sandpaper/knife for a few seconds to enlarge the hole. Just be careful not to make the holes too big.

Once the hands are attached move them both to midnight and then set the correct time using the dial on the back.

If you want you can add a minute hand to the clock as well. To do that take the red minute hand that comes with the clock movement and cut it down to a length that fits the clock.

Step 4

Insert the front part into the back of the clock. Remember to twist the front legs to such an angle that the prongs on the front can pass through.

Step 5

In the final step you fixate the front to the back by rotating the front legs approximately 15 degrees as seen in the image. This will put part of the legs behind the prongs attached to the front, making the case impossible to disassemble. To detach the front you need to turn the legs to their previous position.

Remember to avoid using force when twisting the legs, or else the prongs on the front might break.

 
And you're done! If you decide to make the clock please upload pictures. I'd love to see the results of using different colours and materials!

 

Download Design

Creality CR-10

Resolution:

20%

Since I was not able to find a dual extrusion carriage that met my ideas, I decided to create my own.
The carriage holds two E3Dv6 bowden hotends. i decided to use a single 40mm fan to cool them. the second hotend can be moved vertically for about 1.6mm for nozzle levelling. To do so, remove the front fan and loosen the Center screw a bit. if the screw is fastened, the hotent will not move anymore.
It is designed to use the RJ4JP-01-08 drylin Bearings and a radial fan for material cooling.
If you choose not to use the cable chain adapter, you can put in the "filling", which will guarantee the stability.
when printing you will Need Supports for the "Extruder Mount front" and "cable chain Adapter".
What you will Need:
4x RJ4JP-01-08 Drylin Bearing
7x M3x25mm (for carriage)
1x M3x30mm (for carriage)
1xM325mm (for extruder mount)
9x M3 nut
4x M3x20mm (for front fan)
2x M4x20 (for rear fan)
1x fan 40x6mm
1x radial fan 40mm (the stock one from Anet A8)
of course 2x e3dv6 hotend :)

All parts are tight-fit.
Please mske sure, the front fan runs, whenever the extruder is hot. The mount will deform imediately, if there is no cooling. I wasted two of them during the set up for dual extrusion. :D

I did not design a nozzle for material cooling yet. Feel free to do so and let me know.

Printer:

Anet a8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2

Infill:

20

title: Effector for Ultibots D300 with 55 mm spacing

description.text:
Simple effector for Delta's like the Ultibots D300.
It uses ball and cup joints with a arm spacing of 55 mm. It is intended for a single E3D V6 hot end. And the Nimble of course! It uses the Groove mount adapter that is standard with the Nimble. This ensures that the Nimble is mounted concentric to the hot end.
Also included are holders for a Berd-Air system. Just simple little eyelets to hold the air pipe.

The Nimble Extruder

With an installed weight of less than 27 grams on your carriage/effector the Zesty Nimble is smallest and lightest extruder you can buy, it has ample torque and can be mounted in multiple orientations.

The Nimble is available from Zesty Technology.

author: ZestyTech

title: E3D Chimera Mount for D-Bot (optional BLTouch)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a screw-on bracket for the D-bot print carriage for the E3D Chimera hot end. There is another option on here, but it replaces the entire front plate of the carriage, and I wanted to be able to more easily remove it without having to re-tension the betts, etc, by disassembling the carriage assembly itself. This screws onto the four mounting bolt locations used by the stock assembly without any modification.

There are two versions, with and without a bracket for a BLTouch sensor, and there's a matching tubing bracket for the top of the carriage, spaced to match the two bowden tubes coming out of the Chimera.

The extruder can be bolted to the bracket using the rear or the top screws. I actually did both -- two on top and one in the rear.

I think this might work with a Cyclops, as I believe the dimensions are the same, but no promises. If you try it, let me know if it works.

Edit: E3D seems to have made a change to the hot-end heat-sink. The newer ones are 32mm wide, not 30mm. I don't have one to verify fitment, but I've uploaded an experimental 32mm wide one.

comments.author: jskala

comments.text: I use RepRapFirmware, so its set up differently, but logically speaking that looks correct.
comments.author: jskala

comments.text: Thanks, I think I got it working. Just had some strange things happening on Probes. But I think I got it. What are you guys that use this mount using for a layer fan? Stock? Or something else?
comments.author: dotorg

comments.text: I use the stock one. It's not great, but it works. I've fiddled with a few different designs, but haven't come up with one I like yet. It's on my list of things to get back to at some point.
comments.author: jskala

comments.text: If you ever want someone to test one out let me know would be glad to do so.
comments.author: dotorg

comments.text: What are the offsets for bltouch to hotend ?
comments.author: jskala

comments.text: 21mm to the left hotend (which is the primary on my setup), for the 30mm Chimera mount. The 32mm one, I think I moved it 1mm further out. Although in the grand scheme of things, the BLTouch is so inaccurate, and bed slope even if you're off by a lot is so slight, a millimeter one way or another won't impact calibration at all.
comments.author: jskala

comments.text: Thank you so much.
comments.author: dotorg

comments.text: I don't know if they changed the dimensions, or if my printer is is off on the scale or something, but the chimera hotend I just ordered from E3D definitely doesn't fit this mount. The heatsink is 32mm wide, and the mount has room for a 30mm heatsink. Is that the size it's supposed to be?
comments.author: Jasonpgr

comments.text: https://e3d-online.dozuki.com/Document/NqGb5hDhK3mDdbQC/.pdf
comments.author: Jasonpgr

comments.text: I got it from Filastruder.com which looks like a super reputable seller. I just checked that document and it's definitely supposed to be a 30mm heatsink. I was just hunting around on their site and I got an updated version, but I guess I messed up and didn't double check the description and see that they reworked the cold side as well as the hot side..... any chance you can update this to fit the new design? I just found the dimensions for the new design. https://e3d-online.dozuki.com/Document/rrJKuS5RpGdpJFgS/.pdf
comments.author: dotorg

comments.text: I just uploaded a 32mm version. It was kinda-sorta parametric enough to make the change. I had to switch around where some reference points were on it. I eyeballed the measurements and I think they're correct. If you print it and it fits, let me know. I uploaded a BLTouch version, because that was part of the size change I was less certain of. If it fits the new heat-sink, I can upload a non-BLTouch version as well.
comments.author: Jasonpgr

comments.text: Fantastic. I have it printing now so I'll let you know this evening if it fits.
comments.author: dotorg

comments.text: I just checked on the part and it had already finished printing. It fits the heatsink width and the screw/mounting holes in the top and back perfectly, but the distance between the filament ports on top aren't quite right anymore. I think the new heatsink has them 2mm further apart since the overall dimension is wider by the same amount.
comments.author: Jasonpgr

comments.text: Ah crap. I missed that one. Yeah, its 2mm wider between them, too. (Its a nice change -- the old design didn't have room for two silicone socks, which I'd bet is why they made it wider.)
comments.author: Jasonpgr

comments.text: That's perfect, thank you! Were you going to be able to upload the BLTouch version with the new dimensions as well? When I just checked there was only the base version without the added BLTouch portion.
comments.author: dotorg

comments.text: Okay, not sure what happened there. Fusion360 got wedged, and actually exported the wrong version of it, and I didn't even notice. I had to restart it, and re-upload it again. The one now should be right. (The one a bit ago had the D-Bot bracket embedded in it, and no BLTouch, for some reason...)
comments.author: Jasonpgr

comments.text: Awesome, printer is heating up, and I'll be able to get the print started before I head back out to work. I'll let you know for sure if it fits when I get back.
comments.author: dotorg

comments.text: Woah, not sure what happened there. That one is completely wrong. Give me a minute to figure out what happened.
comments.author: Jasonpgr

description.text:
Blue Spirit mask split into 12 pieces. I printed this on an UP! Plus 2 so the pieces should require at most 150x150mm bed size, maybe smaller.

All credit for the model goes to JTM
A simple phone jack dust protector

I wanted a phone holder for my Samsung Note 3 on my desk hence came out with this design. Modeling done with Solidworks and converted into STL files. I printed this with my 3D printer at 0.2 resolution. Bear in mind certain PLA material might have 2% shrinkage within the first 24 hours after printed. In that case you should scale up to compensate this shrinkage.

I created 2 part separately so i can print them flat on the bed instead of having supporting material and post treatment. These 2 parts were joined with 2 screw. Simple and easy.

Printer:

Anycubic i3 Mega

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

0.2

title: Anet A6 - Frankenstein IR sensor mount (auto leveling)

description.text:
This is a sensor mount for David Crocker's mini height sensor board. You can find the details here:

https://miscsolutions.wordpress.com/mini-height-sensor-board/

The sensor mount is positioned on the back of the Frankenstein and replaces the small X axis limit switch holder, which is integrated here.

The sensor board is mounted on the inside of the mount with its back facing towards the nozzle.

08/09/17 - new Version v2:

  • back parts thickened for better stability
  • moved sensor 5mm further towards the nozzle (now it should be 33mm behind)
  • removed endstop mounting plate (not used on my printer, because the endstop switch is mounted on the left side of the x axis

Setup parameters

Z Probe offset in Marlin

You have to modifiy the probe position in your Marlin source accordingly. This mount positions the board directly behind the nozzle, so

  • X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER should be 0
    (from David Crocker's page: "The sensing area is approximately in the middle of the bottom edge of the board, below the cylindrical capacitor.")

  • Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER should be somewhere in the range of 30 to 35 mm (positive values = behind the nozzle)

Z Probe bed position

As the probe is exactly behind the nozzle you should be able to take measurements relatively close to the right and left edge of the hotbed. Perhaps values like

  • LEFT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 15
  • RIGHT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 205

should be fine.

For the front you need to take into account, that the sensor is behind the nozzle, so if the nozzle is at 0, the sensor is round about at 30 or so. You can perhaps try it with

  • FRONT_PROBE_BED_POSITION 45

The back position is opposite to the front, so perhaps you start with somewhat like

  • BACK_PROBE_BED_POSITION 175

FOR SURE YOU HAVE TO FIND OUT THE EXACT POSITIONS ON YOUR OWN. I can't be held responsible if anything goes wrong! Just be warned ;-)

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50% or more

Notes:

Print in PETG or ABS because of their heat resistance.

It is possible, that you have to widen the sensor board mounting holes (so that they look like a vertical oval slot), to bring the lower edge of the sensor board down. This simply depends on how your hotend is mounted inside the Frankenstein. Use a drill or a file to change the holes.

regarding v2:
I lowered the mounting holes a bit, so that you should not need to modify the holes. Adjust the height of the nozzle so that it is about 1.5mm below the sensor and you should be fine.

This mount is designed using SketchUp and Fusion 360, hence some strange faces when opening the archive under Fusion 360 :) - perhaps I shouId have redone it completely in Fusion 360, but I was too lazy :D - I added the Fusion archive file so that you can modify it to your needs. It replaces the original X axis limit switch holder (10_x_axis_sensor.stl) of the Frankenstein. The limit switch holder is integrated in this mount.

author: pandel

description.text:
Parametric, straight pipe pieces.
This is a test for making a pan flute. A pipe for the tone C has to be 160 mm long, thus the pips must be printed and joined. There is a tolearnce of .2mm in the radius of the lip.

print it, see if it works, tell me about it
(as i dont have a 3d printer) You can change the length of the connecting lip (hlip), the minimal wall thickness your printer can print (dxmin), the tolerance between inside of pipe outside of the lip(wslip=.2) to optimise the fit in the openscad file. I'm learing to use the command line option of openscad. So expect .stl's with differnt parameters to find the best fit i the next days.

description.text:
This is my take on the wall mounted spool holder. I designed this part to save on material while still being very durable since multiple full spools of filament and a wooden rod is pretty heavy. It holds up great.

I purchased the wooden rod from Home Depot. It pretty much a closet rod for hanging cloths. I also purchased the screws and anchor from Home Depot (exact picture above).

The tolerance on the hole for the wooden rod is pretty tight this way you won't need to screw it in place and it hold really well in there by friction without falling off the wall while printing, which would suck. To add or remove spools I just twist a push on one side of the rod until it out of the whole.
